definitions.definition: baked clay used for building walls, houses and other buildings; an individual block of this

examples.text: The school is built of brick.
He got a job at the local brick works.
Conservationists moved the whole house, brick by brick.
They put an extra course of bricks around the pool.
We rebuilt the fireplace using salvaged bricks.

definitions.definition: a plastic or wooden block, used as a toy for young children to build things with
a friend that you can rely on when you need help

examples.text: Thanks for looking after the children today—you're a real brick.

definitions.definition: to keep trying to do something that will never be successful

examples.text: Trying to reason with them was like banging my head against a brick wall.

definitions.definition: to be unable to make any progress because there is a difficulty that stops you
to say something that offends or embarrasses somebody, although you did not intend to

examples.text: She was like a cat on hot bricks before her driving test.
She was like a cat on a hot tin roof before her driving test.
Disappointment hit her like a ton of bricks.
They **came down on him like a ton of bricks** *(= criticized him very severely)*.

definitions.definition: to try to work without the necessary material, money, information, etc.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Middle Low German, Middle Dutch bricke, brike; probably reinforced by Old French brique; of unknown ultimate origin.
